bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, December 6, 1921

div1.p: Hanson refutes Dr. Arces' theory that yellow fever does not exist in Peru. He expresses confidence in the work being done.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, December 6, 1921
div1.opener:
DIRECCION DE LA CAMPAÑA SANITARIA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
EN LOS
DEPARTAMENTOS DEL NORTE
____
OFICINA CENTRAL
____
Hanson
(see Rose
Chiclayo, Peru.
December 6, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
We have completed the translation and the copying of
your article on the Spontaneous Elimination of Yellow Fever from Endemic
Centers. Enclosed you will find a copy and presume that you will revise
and notify either me or Dr. Rose about any errors which may be found. I
have sent one copy to White and one to Rose. I am also sending a copy to
the Sambridad. I have previously sent them copy of the translation made
by Rivers of the two lectures which you delivered before the U.S.P.H.S.
and Dr. Eyzaguire, the Statistician, told me that they were going to have
these lectures reproduced.

I was under the impression that I had sent you a copy of the
reply I made to Dr. Julian Arces, harangue on the error(?) of considering
the recent epidemics as yellow fever. I find no record of having done so
and am therefore inflicting this on you. I hope you will critizise where
I am in error in this letter.

We are now in the midst of arranging all our records and files
preparatory to taking them to Lima wjere we will establish the principal
office from now on to the end of the campaign. As you know we have extended the
work to the south and will have the bulk of it to do there. I feel very con-
fident of the northern sections, and with Mr. Seeley continuously on the
job up here and with Dr. Canseco as the local medical director I see no dan-
ger from this section from now on. I shall visit up here as frequently as
the campaign of the south will permit, so as not to get out of touch with
the progress of events. Our percentage is actually down to and below one,
and under such conditions there can be no danger.

We have distributed fish in everything, and are still keeping it
up. We have practically reach the half-million mark with our fish distribution.
The actual numbers of fish bought is about 480 000, and how many more we will
use I can not yet day. It all depends on how things will appear in our work in
the south. We have set out to make sure of the thing this year and we dont
want to have the disappointment which you had last year. I have wondered abo
about this,- whether there was not some ultimate good in the fact that the
epidemic showed up here. I am inclined to be sceptical about the supposed
absence of the fever in these Departments last year. Their appearance this
year has taught us a lesson which is eventually worth something, in as much
as we are now talking about the completelimination of the disease from this
coast, it is better to be scared into the necessity of making a general
clean up of everything which might later serve to defeat our purpose. That
is what we are doing now.

The letter from Dr. Rose, dated November 2, is a sort of unlimited
blanket authority. I am very conceited over receiving a letter of that kind,
and I had it translated that I might use it with some of the local people.
I hope that we shall soon be able to show the results which are expected.

I have arranged for the family to come back and am expecting thm
in Pimented tomorrow. They will come ashore and remain until D go to Lima,
we have obtained a furnished house in Miraflores, so th y will stay there
until I get through. I fully expect that by May there will be no object
in having us continue longer.

Dr. Rose says that when the work is finished, I will prepare a
report, does he mean that I am to do this before leaving here or after I
get back to the states. A proper report on this campaign is a thing which ca
can not be done in a hurry. We will have about two or three thousand pages
of files and records to review for this report. We are doing what we can
now to get things in shape, but to get this up as it should be will re-
quire time and hard work.

My Address from now on will be Lima, either in care of the
American Consul or just Lima will reach me O.K.
